item.title: GitHub Pages Easter Egg: Deploying Multiple Pages
item.description:
Recently, my biological clock has been a bit off, still messing around with GitHub Pages deployments at nearly 2 AM.

I went to eat after work, and I just wanted to sleep as soon as I finished eating. After eating, I came back around 8:30 PM, feeling drowsy, I thought about taking a nap, and then fell asleep immediately. When I woke up, it was already nearly 2 AM.

Categories that haven’t even launched yet: AI Study Group

Facepalm

Yesterday we said there wouldn’t be much frontend development, but today it’s not frontend – it’s the experience of UI/UX.

Project

Please join our old friend, https://github.com/ttf248/ai-coding-demo. That’s the original self-selected stock project – we’re restructuring the overall project structure, and all subsequent AI programming content will be housed within this project.

Deploying Multiple Pages

The project is hosted domestically at [https://cnb.cool/ttf248/ai-coding-demo]. Due to well-known reasons, pages cannot be published within China, so we need to publish them on GitHub outside of the country.

The blog is published on this external GitHub. I haven’t tried it before, and also, the current project I’m working on isn’t a traditional blog site; it simply contains a lot of documentation layered with several static HTML design mockups.

That’s right – this page is where I first discovered that deploying multiple pages using Pages doesn’t affect the blog’s publication, but instead adds a new path under the blog’s domain name.

[https://ttf248.life/ai-coding-demo/](https://ttf248.

AI Study Group

Yesterday, I created a new category and thought about using AI to learn many computer courses, such as algorithms and LeetCode practice problems. Each learning record is published on the blog to form a knowledge base. A new category was created: AI Study Group. Now it seems that different courses require creating separate projects, and all learning notes are written in the project’s Readme.md file.

item.title: Old problems, the flamboyant beauty of blossoming flowers (a reference to a famous Chinese poem).
item.description:
For many years, I’ve focused on backend development, and recently started to explore AI programming while dipping my toes into some frontend-related content. However, during this period of tinkering, I gradually realized I was falling back into an old habit – being dazzled by shiny new things. I constantly try to use AI to create a frontend interface, but in reality, these attempts haven’t provided much practical benefit for my current work and are actually diverting my attention.

AI Use Cases

In small projects, AI tools can truly shine, particularly when writing independent functions with low coupling to the system and simple business logic. These tasks typically have clear inputs and outputs, and rely less on context – making them well-suited for the current capabilities of AI-assisted programming.

However, when facing complex system architectures or deep business logic, the limitations of AI become increasingly apparent. It may generate code that appears reasonable but is actually detached from the project’s real needs, or even introduce potential issues that are difficult to debug. In these scenarios, AI is best suited as an assistive tool rather than a fully autonomous code generator. We need to conduct rigorous review and testing of any generated code to ensure it meets actual requirements.

Errors and the Cost of Learning

While attempting to generate frontend code using AI, I encountered numerous challenges. As frontend development isn’t my area of expertise, troubleshooting often proved time-consuming and frustrating. Even after adjusting prompts to have the AI rewrite the code, it was difficult to avoid the appearance of some low-level errors. This iterative process not only wasted time but also highlighted that my current focus should be on backend business logic rather than exploring unfamiliar domains.

Looking back at the project completed over the weekend, I’m more confident that focusing on backend development and user interaction logic, implementing functionality through a console, is the most efficient approach currently. Perhaps systematically learning frontend knowledge would be a better strategy when I have more time and energy.

Frontend Learning Plan

The frontend technology stack is complex and diverse, so it’s unrealistic to quickly master it. I plan to first choose a framework, such as Vue.js or React.js, and deeply learn its core concepts and usage methods. Only after becoming familiar with the fundamentals will I attempt to use AI to generate frontend code, which can effectively avoid errors and wasted time caused by unfamiliarity.

In short, the focus for this stage should be on backend development, steadily building up my core skills. Once the timing is right, I’ll explore the combination of frontend and AI – potentially yielding greater rewards.

item.title: Claude4 released, attempting to develop: Hugo tags, hyperlink translation assistant
item.description:
This site is developed using Hugo, but I’ve always used Chinese titles, which results in less friendly generated article links. In simpler terms, when shared, they don’t look as good because the Chinese characters are escaped into formats like %E4%BD%A0%E5%A5%BD within the links. While you can solve this by setting a slug, it’s tedious to do manually every time.

Therefore, I decided to try using Claude4 to develop a translation assistant that automatically converts Chinese titles to English slugs and adds hyperlinks within the articles. This would eliminate the need for manual setup.

Claude4 is amazing – its contextual understanding has significantly improved, as has its efficiency in handling complex tasks.

Project Address

Domestic Project Address: https://cnb.cool/ttf248/hugo-content-suite International Project Address: https://github.com/ttf248/hugo-content-suite

Code Implementation

Let’s first discuss the implementation approach: We need to scan all articles, extract tag information and article titles, and then call the local large model (such as gemma-3-12b-it) for translation.

In actual development, Claude4 showcased several significant advantages compared to previous generation large models. Due to the diverse functional requirements, Claude4 automatically designed an interactive menu, comprehensively considering various usage scenarios. For example, in tag processing, Claude4 not only supports tag statistics and analysis but also includes classification statistics, and can even detect unlabeled articles. Furthermore, it provides preview and tag page generation functionalities.

Whether it’s integrating with the local large model, adding translation caches, or performing large-scale code refactoring, Claude4 completes everything in one go, with almost no issues. Despite the project’s small scale, it incorporates many minor features. In previous development cycles with large models, there was often a tendency to forget earlier content; however, Claude 4 performed exceptionally well, virtually eliminating context loss.

In short, its intelligence has increased, and we plan to switch to Claude 4 for more development work as our primary coding model.

Translation Cache

This approach, besides reducing the number of calls to large models, is quite efficient when running a 12b model locally – it doesn’t waste much time. However, if you need to call the large model every time, it will still be somewhat slow. Secondly, to fix the connections within articles, if a full update operation is executed and the article title is very long, there’s occasionally a situation where the two translated results differ, causing the link to change – which is quite awkward.

Feature Optimization

The entire project was handed over to Claude4 to analyze the space for optimization and generate the following recommendations:

Reviewed the code, which had no issues whatsoever. For example, the configuration files were reviewed, and the original code’s configurations were converted into default configurations. When reading the configuration file, if a corresponding configuration file did not exist, a default configuration file would be automatically generated to avoid user operational errors. Here’s the English translation of the provided text:

“Requirements: When translating, dynamically calculate the current translation efficiency, estimate remaining time, and output relevant information to the console. Currently, we’re obtaining the character count of the article, the number of characters translated per line, the time taken, and fitting a calculation for the translation time of every 100 characters. Simultaneously, we’re calculating the estimated remaining translation time.

The code is complete, but the effect isn’t satisfactory, so I ask AI to provide a new design solution:

  • Provide multiple efficiency calculation methods: real-time efficiency, average efficiency, and sliding window efficiency
  • Improve display format: progress bar, segmented statistics, dynamic refresh
  • Add more useful metrics: API call counts, success rates.

After completing the code, we discovered a new surprise – translation efficiency statistics were flooding the console in real time, but without endless scrolling.” Here’s the English translation of the provided text:

item.title: Multi-dimensional impacts of the family planning policy: deep transformations from social structure to economic and political changes.
item.description:
China’s population control policies, while limiting growth and curbing family-style development, have disrupted traditional social structures, suppressed the expansion of family-owned businesses and political dynasty power, presenting a unique case compared to Korean conglomerates and Indian family monopolies. Now that birth restrictions are being relaxed, despite facing challenges such as low fertility rates, it’s crucial to be wary of new monopoly risks and seek balance through multiple avenues.

One: The Tension Between Population Control and Family-Style Development

The family planning policy, implemented in China for nearly forty years as a basic national strategy, has achieved significant direct results. Data shows that from 1978 to 2007, China’s natural population growth rate declined from 12‰ to 5.2‰, resulting in a reduction of over 40 million people, and the country’s share of the world’s population decreased from 22.2% to 20.1%. This sharp deceleration in population growth profoundly reshaped China’s social family structure. Taking family-owned enterprises as an example, after the implementation of the family planning policy, the number of children born by business owners significantly declined: before the policy, the proportion of those having three or more children reached 40.63%, and after the policy it plummeted to 18.46%, the proportion of single sons born increased from 6.25% to 32.31%. This structural change directly reduced the range of potential internal successors for family-owned enterprises, objectively suppressing their generational expansion capabilities.

One: The Tension Between Population Control and Familial Development

Comparing Korea and India reveals significant differences. While Korea did not implement strict birth control measures, fertility rates have remained low for a long time (0.7 in 2023), the chaebols still firmly control the nation’s economic lifeline through cross-shareholdings and tax avoidance strategies like inheritance taxes. The top five chaebols account for over 50% of Korea’s GDP, with Samsung Group alone contributing 20%. India presents a contrasting picture: 79% of its economic output is generated by family-owned businesses, with six major conglomerates controlling key sectors such as telecommunications and steel, and the top 20 enterprises earning 80% of national corporate profits. The core difference lies in the fact that China’s population control policies limited family sizes, thereby weakening the human resources base for chaebol expansion at its source. Due to different policy environments, familial power has continued to penetrate economic sectors in Korea and India.

II. Monopoly Restraint and Social Structural Transformation

The impact of the family planning policy on the economic sector is particularly evident in its suppression of monopolistic phenomena. Due to declining birth rates, Chinese family businesses have struggled to form conglomerates akin to those in South Korea and Japan. Taking South Korea as an example, chaebols maintained their control through “circular capital” investments, with the Samsung family holding only 2% of the group’s shares while wielding overall control through complex equity structures. Conversely, in China, post-family planning, family businesses generally faced difficulties in “passing down the business” to heirs, necessitating the introduction of professional managers or implementing equity diversification reforms. According to a湃新闻 (Papare News) study, the proportion of female successors in family businesses after family planning has increased from 13.85% to 34.21%, and the education level of these successors has significantly improved, with the percentage of undergraduates rising from 43.75% to 98.46%. This transition, while not completely eliminating family control, significantly reduced the possibility of a single family monopolizing the market.

At the social structure level, the population planning policy accelerated the breakdown of traditional family core patterns. China’s average household size decreased from 4.41 people/household in 1982 to 2.62 people/household in 2020, with smaller families weakening the family’s functions in areas such as economics, education, and social support. In contrast, India maintains an average family size of around 4 people, with the caste system deeply intertwined with family power, leading to low social mobility. China’s transformation of its family structure created space for individualism; in 2023, China had 240 million single adult citizens, and a trend of “one-person economy” emerged in the consumer market, further diminishing the influence of family economies.

Three. Decentralization of Power in the Political Sphere

The impact of the family planning policy on the political ecology has been profound. Traditionally, family power structures had infiltrated grassroots politics through bloodlines and kinship relationships. For example, in Henan’s Xinye County, 161 political families almost controlled all government departments, with 20% of cadres at deputy-officer level or above belonging to “officer’s children.” However, after the implementation of the family planning policy, the shrinking family size limited the expansion of family networks. Research from Peking University showed that after family planning, the number of offspring of officials decreased, and the complexity of family political networks significantly declined. Furthermore, the policy-driven promotion of education (the average years of schooling increased from 5.2 in 1982 to 10.9 in 2023) facilitated social mobility, weakening the monopoly of family power over political resources. Comparing Korea and India, the deep entanglement between Korean conglomerates (like Samsung Group executives and government corruption) and India’s caste-based hereditary political lineage highlights the uniqueness of Chinese policy. China, through its population control policies, objectively reduced the possibility of power succession. While familial phenomena still exist within county-level politics, the overall trend is towards a decentralization of power structures. During the 2025 National People’s Congress (NPC) session, an NPC delegate proposed renaming “The Population and Family Planning Law” to “The Population and Reproduction Law,” fully opening up birth limits – a move that could further influence the evolution of future political ecosystems.

Four. Challenges and Opportunities Following Policy Adjustments

The implementation of the 2016 nationwide two-child policy and the 2021 three-child policy marked a significant shift in China’s birth policies. However, the policy effects were limited: births in 2022 totaled only 1.18, far below the replacement level (2.1). The relaxation of birth restrictions had a dual impact on family-owned businesses: on one hand, some entrepreneurs may strengthen family succession capabilities through multiple births, such as Zong Qinghou’s daughter, Zong Fufeng, who took over as the sole heir to Wahaha Group; on the other hand, high childcare costs (the average cost of raising a child to 18 years old in first-tier cities reaching 1 million yuan) and declining fertility intentions among professional women limited family size expansion.

In the economic sphere, relaxing birth restrictions may give rise to new monopoly forms. The three-child policy has driven consolidation in the maternal and childcare industries, with the estimated market size for infant care expected to reach 1621 by 2025. - 300 million yuan

  • Leading enterprises are utilizing mergers and acquisitions to integrate smaller manufacturers, resulting in a CR5 market concentration exceeding 55%. This increase in concentration may bring about efficiency gains, but it also warrants vigilance against new monopoly risks. The government needs to strike a balance between encouraging childbirth and preventing market consolidation, such as strengthening regulation through antitrust laws while providing childcare subsidies (e.g., Hangzhou’s three-child families receiving RMB 3,000 per month in milk powder subsidies) to alleviate household burdens.

  • In the political sphere, relaxing birth restrictions could have subtle impacts on family power structures. While it is unlikely to restore traditional family political networks in the short term, over the long term, larger families may form new influence within grassroots politics. Therefore, refining personnel selection mechanisms and strengthening oversight (such as establishing a nepotism avoidance system for officials) remains crucial in preventing hereditary power.

Five. International Mirroring and Future Outlook

The experiences of South Korea and India demonstrate a close correlation between the ebb and flow of family power structures and policy orientations. South Korea achieved economic takeoff by supporting conglomerates, but at the cost of social inequality; India’s failure to implement effective policies to curb family monopolies has exacerbated wealth disparity. China’s population control policy effectively controlled population growth while also suppressing the expansion of family power, yet it resulted in issues such as an aging population and labor shortages.

Looking ahead, China needs to find a new balance between population policy and socio-economic development. On one hand, implementing fertility support policies (such as extending maternity leave and building universal childcare institutions) should boost birth rates; on the other hand, strengthening antitrust enforcement is crucial to prevent family businesses from forming new monopolies through capital operations. In the political sphere, further progress must be made in grassroots democratic construction, with enhanced oversight mechanisms to ensure transparency in governance. Ultimately, the family planning policy served as a key driver of social transformation in China; its impact extended far beyond population issues. It reshaped family structures, economic models, and the political landscape, providing a path for China to avoid falling into the trap of family monopolies like those seen in Korea and India. With the policy’s adjustment, how to balance efficiency and equity, freedom and order within the new demographic context will be a long-term challenge facing China.

item.title: AI overuse can lead to some lingering effects.
item.description:
Since we’ve established “AI Inspiration Collision Forum,” there’s been a lot of noise – many things, both good and bad – being tried out using AI for recording and publishing, and less time spent on quiet self-reflection. It feels like this is becoming increasingly rare. Moving forward, it would be beneficial to slightly control the output of this section and consolidate it into a monthly magazine format, releasing one article per month.

This is almost like a post-traumatic effect – or a side effect – where efficiency has increased, but the depth and breadth of thought have declined.

Efficiency Boost: Undeniable

The “Seven-Second Fish Sightseeing” column used to be poorly maintained, with only a few hot events covered. Due to laziness, I hadn’t searched the internet for relevant materials or compiled notes. Now that various AI tools are available, all it takes is outlining the key points, and AI can automatically search for related events, generate articles as needed, simply format them, and publish them.

It’s like a blessing for lazy people – efficiency has increased significantly, almost to the point of doubling effort.

Beyond writing articles, efficiency gains are real when coding. Previously, writing code often required detailed reading of API interface documentation. Now, I can skip this entirely. This is incredibly valuable because familiarizing oneself with APIs is “physical labor,” not “mental labor.” AI handles this part perfectly.

Spam Content

Many articles have poor quality content, not to say that there’s nothing there; it just doesn’t read well, lacking a sense of reality and what people actually experience. This is a style I previously disliked – like chewing wax.

From another perspective, AI-generated content really does feel like products of a流水线 (liú shuǐ liàn - assembly line) production, lacking soul.

Spam of the New Internet

Forgetting

This type of document is entirely AI-generated, and the reader’s context is unclear. However, over time, my own impressions will become blurred, or even forgotten.

Similar issues occur when writing code – without reviewing commit records, I can’t remember how I originally thought about it, or why I wrote it that way. This is particularly evident with code generated through repeated communication with AI, where the final code differs significantly from the initial ideas, sometimes drastically so.

Search

Recently, the number of times I’ve opened Google and Baidu has noticeably decreased. Many questions are now being answered by AI for searching and interaction, and the results are much better than traditional search engines.

Let’s mourn the bing ai, which may no longer be active, a pioneering AI tool from a major company that could connect to the internet and search.

I’m using Google less, and I’ve reduced my visits to stackoverflow as well – many questions are now simply asked of AI, and this website is gradually being phased out by the times.

Conclusion

My maintained blog, originally with very little traffic, is now even less expected of; it’s primarily a place for self-reflection and recording.

item.title: Trade war abruptly called a pause
item.description:
The evolution of trade war tariffs in 2025 presented a “escalation – counter-repressive measures – negotiations” cycle, with the US-China rivalry shifting from tariff confrontation to competition over rules. Despite short-term easing that alleviated market pressure, long-term uncertainty remains, and it’s crucial to monitor WTO rulings, supply chain adjustments, and geopolitical shifts’ sustained impact on the global economy.

People don’t earn money beyond their own cognitive expectations; the stock market crash triggered by the launch of the trade war this year has largely been recovered, but countless small investors have been buried along the way.

2025 Trade War Tariff Timeline Overview

Here is a timeline of the trade war tariff events, combining key events involving the US and China, and other countries, to present the dynamic evolution of tariff policies:

I. April 2025: Comprehensive Upgrade and Countermeasures on Tariffs

  1. U.S. Tariff Measures Against China
    • April 2nd: The Trump administration signed Executive Order No. 14257, announcing the imposition of a 34% “retaliatory tariff” on goods exported from China to the U.S., covering products originating in Hong Kong and Macao.
    • April 8th: The United States further increased the “retaliatory tariff” rate on Chinese goods from 34% to 84%, and signed Executive Orders No. 14259 and 14266, imposing tariffs on additional products.
    • April 10th: The White House amended the executive order, increasing the total tariff amount against China to 145%, and raising the tariff rate on small packages (such as goods priced below $800 from 90% to 120%).
  • China’s Countermeasures
    • April 4th: China announced the imposition of a 34% tariff on all goods originating in the United States, covering sectors such as agricultural products, automobiles, and energy. - April 10th: China will retaliate against the tariff rate increase from 34% to 84%, in sync with the US side.
    • April 12th: China cancels the additional tariffs imposed on U.S. goods by 91% (corresponding to some of the cancellation by the US side) and suspends the implementation of 24% tariffs for 90 days, retaining 10%.

I. April 2025: Comprehensive Tariff Upgrade and Countermeasures

  • Tariff Games Involving Other Countries
    • US-Canada Trade War: The United States imposes 25% tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum products, and Canada retaliates by taxing goods worth $298 billion from the US, as well as filing a WTO dispute.
    • EU & Japan: The EU imposes maximum 25% tariffs on US goods, while Japan expresses concern over auto tariffs imposed by the US, calling the trade war “harming both sides.”

II. May 2025: Geneva Talks and Tariff De-escalation

  1. US-China High-Level Trade Talks
    • May 10-11: The US and China held a 16-hour meeting in Geneva, Switzerland, reaching the “Joint Statement on the US-China Economic Dialogue” (also known as the Geneva Accord).
    • May 12: Both sides announced a suspension of some tariffs:
      • The United States paused its 24% tariff on Chinese goods (for 90 days), retaining 10%, and rescinded the additional tariffs imposed on April 8th and 9th.
      • China simultaneously suspended its 24% retaliatory tariffs, retaining 10%, and lifted non-tariff measures.
    • Establishment of a Consultation Mechanism: Both sides agreed to hold regular trade consultations in China, the United States, or a third country, focusing on tariff reduction and rulemaking.
  • Economic Impact & Policy Adjustments
    • US Domestic Pressure: High tariffs led to the closure of small and medium-sized enterprises (such as Amazon sellers forced to close due to tariff surges) and rising inflation expectations (core PCE is expected to rise to 3…

III. Other Key Events and Long-Term Impacts

  1. WTO and Multilateral Responses

    • Canada and China both lodged WTO disputes against the U.S. steel and aluminum tariffs and “retaliatory tariffs,” alleging violations of non-discrimination principles.
    • WTO Director-General Azevedo warned that U.S. tariffs could cause a 1% contraction in global trade volumes by 2025, exacerbating difficulties for developing countries.

  2. Exemption Lists and Industry Impacts

    • U.S. Excluded Goods: A 37-page list covering strategic materials such as rare earths, graphite, and medical CT balls exposed supply chain vulnerabilities.
    • Auto Tariffs: The U.S. imposed 25% tariffs on imported automobiles, leading to an estimated 2% decline in global auto production and a 9% reduction in North American output.

  3. Political and Strategic Maneuvering

    • The Trump administration attempted to reshape the international trade order through “retaliatory tariffs,” but was criticized as unilateral bullying, triggering backlash from allies (such as the EU and Japan).

Four. Timeline Summary

Time Event
April 2, 2025 The United States imposes additional tariffs of 34% on goods from Hong Kong and Macau.

Four. Timeline Summary

Time Event
April 8th The United States raised tariffs on Chinese imports to 84% and added new executive orders.

Four. Timeline Summary

Time Event
April 10th China retaliates by imposing a 34% tariff, later raised to 84%; the US adjusts tariffs to 145%.

Four. Timeline Summary

Time Event
April 12th The United States waived some goods (such as technology products), China lifted 91% of the counter-tariffs.

Four. Timeline Summary

Time Event
May 10-11 US-China talks in Geneva, reaching a joint statement on suspending tariffs by 24% (90 days).

Four. Timeline Summary

Time Event
May 12th Both sides announced a suspension of tariffs and the establishment of a consultation mechanism, easing trade tensions.

Five. Trends and Challenges

  • Short-Term Relief and Long-Term Competition: The suspension of US-China tariffs sent positive signals, but structural issues (such as high technology and energy) remain, with midterm elections or policy continuity impacting the medium term.
  • Global Supply Chain Restructuring: Companies are accelerating adjustments to their supply chains, with Mexico and Southeast Asia benefiting from “nearshoring,” but rising costs may dampen recovery.
  • Multilateral Mechanism Dilemmas: The WTO dispute resolution mechanism is limited, regional trade agreements (such as the US-UK agreement) are emerging as alternative options, but this could exacerbate fragmentation.

item.title: 2020-2025 Jiangxi Province Special Postdoctoral and National Civil Service Teacher Recruitment Data: Trends and Insights into Transformation
item.description:
2020-2025 Years: The recruitment of teachers in Jiangxi Province shows a significant reduction trend: the number of specially appointed teachers decreased sharply from 6,617 to 32 (a decrease of 99.5%), and the number of national cadre teachers decreased from 11,324 to 2,146 (a decrease of 81.1%). The proportion of core subjects (Chinese, mathematics, and English) remained stable but declined in total volume; while the proportions of music, art, and physical education increased, the absolute number was limited (e.g., in 2025, they were only recruited 2 people each). Policy-wise, “one withdrawal, one replacement” personnel adjustments have tightened, with teacher resources leaning towards vocational training and remote areas, traditional primary and secondary school positions have significantly reduced, and some subjects plan for zero recruitment in 2025.

The recruitment numbers of specially appointed teachers in Jiangxi Province over the past five years have been collected and compiled into a table, categorized by subject.

item.title: Merge the Pull Request into the Repository of the Fork
item.description:
github-readme-stats is a GitHub profile statistics generator that allows users to display various statistics and charts within their GitHub profiles. It offers multiple customization options to tailor it to user needs.

I manage my repository habits by grouping them by project; GitHub doesn’t support repository grouping, so I have to achieve this by splitting repositories across different organizations. The latest branch of github-readme-stats cannot support statistics for repositories spanning different organizations; I forked a branch and merged the corresponding code.

Final Result

Pull Request Original Address

Adds the ability to include data from organization repositories

Merging a Pull Request into Your Forked Repository

To merge a Pull Request (PR) into your forked repository, there are several ways to do this, depending on whether you want to:

  1. Merge the PR from the upstream repository into your fork, or
  2. Merge a PR from another person’s fork into your fork, or
  3. Merge a PR that was opened on your fork (e.g., someone forked and created a PR for you)

I’ll first give you a common scenario: You have forked a repository and want to merge a PR from the upstream into your fork. Here’s the workflow below 👇

✅ Method One: Command Line (Most Universal)

Step 1: Clone your own fork

Step 2: Add upstream (original repository address)

Step 3: Fetch the Upstream PR Branch

Find the PR number you want to merge, such as PR #123. You can then checkout the code for that PR like this:

Step 4: Switch and Merge Branches

If everything is working correctly, you can push your changes to your forked GitHub repository:

✅ Method Two: GitHub Web Interface (Simple but Limited)

If you see a PR on GitHub’s web interface that is against the upstream repository, you can:

  1. Navigate to the PR page.
  2. Click “Commits” or “Files changed” in the top-right corner to see which branch this PR is based on.
  3. On your fork page, create a new branch and then manually cherry-pick the PR’s commit (requires Git knowledge).
  4. Or, click “Open in GitHub Desktop” and use the GUI tool to merge.

🚀 If someone has created a fork and submitted a PR to it, simply navigate to the PR page, click the “Merge pull request” button, and you’re done.

Would you like me to walk you through it step-by-step based on your specific scenario (e.g., PR link, whether you’re using a web interface or command line)? Or, please provide the link and I can analyze the simplest approach for you.

item.title: The “Tiangong” (Heavenly Palace) incident in medical education and the Butterfly Effect of Dong Xi Ying’s case
item.description:
The Beijing Children’s Hospital “4+4” project (4 years non-medical bachelor’s + 4 years medical doctorate) focuses on interdisciplinary elite cultivation. The exposure of Dong Xi Ying’s case in 2025 revealed her leveraging family background (medical/scientific research lineage) to enter the program, raising concerns about the ambiguity of her qualifications, allegations of plagiarism in her dissertation, and exposing a conflict between the project’s elite recruitment model and fairness. Issues regarding shortened study durations and internship training remain unresolved.

Prompts

Writing a blog: Harmony 4+4 Origin and Development, Core: A Corner of Tian Gong, Seen by Mortals, Dong Xiaojie’s Family Background, Normal Medical Doctor Cannot Graduate in Eight Years, Dong Xiaojie’s Family and Educational Background

Harmony 4+4: Deconstructing Medical Education’s “Tian Gong”

The “4+4” project at the Beijing Union Medical College, since its launch in 2018, has been viewed as China’s “Tian Gong” – or celestial palace – in medical education. This project, designed to mimic the American medical education system, adopted the philosophy of “cultivating multidisciplinary individuals, nurturing loving doctors, and attracting outstanding talents from across the nation.” It aimed to create a rift within traditional Chinese medical education by: replacing the traditional 5+3+3 (five-year bachelor’s degree + three-year master’s degree + three-year doctoral degree) model with a four-year non-medical undergraduate program plus a four-year medical doctorate training. This was intended to cultivate cross-disciplinary leadership talent in medicine.

This project’s “Tian Gong” attributes are reflected across three dimensions:

  1. Elite Recruitment: Early requirements stipulated that applicants must come from QS/Times/US News top 50 universities or US News’s top 10 liberal arts colleges (such as Barnard College), later relaxed to the top 100, but still requiring a GPA of 3.6 or being within the top 30% of their class. Internationalization of Learning Pathways: Adopting an organ-system integration curriculum in the American style, PBL (Problem-Based Learning) methodology, students must complete core courses such as anatomy and pathology within 4 years, and participate in clinical internships.

  2. Controversy Regarding Export Quality: Although the pass rate for practicing physicians (95.2%) is slightly lower than that of traditional eight-year programs (98.5%), graduates predominantly enter affiliated hospitals, and their career development shows no significant difference from traditional pathways.

Dong Xiying Incident: A “Celestial Realm” Crack Revealed by Ordinary Eyes

In April 2025, the extramarital affair involving Xiao Fei, a thoracic surgeon at Zhongdayu Hospital, and his wife was reported, inadvertently exposing the “mysterious veil” of the 4+4 project at Xinhua Hospital. The background of Dong Xiying, the person involved, sparked three key questions:

  1. Ambiguity Regarding Educational Background:
    • Dispute Over Undergraduate Institution: Dong Xiying claimed to have graduated from Columbia University, but actually attended Barnard College (ranked 14th in US News & World Report for liberal arts colleges in 2025). Although the school met Xinhua Hospital’s requirement of “top 20 liberal arts colleges,” its diploma simultaneously listed “Barnard College” and “Columbia University,” which could be easily misinterpreted as Columbia University’s main campus in the domestic recruitment market.
    • Dispute Over Professional Field: An economics undergraduate degree combined with a clinical medicine doctorate path, while aligning with the 4+4 project’s positioning of “multi-disciplinary background,” was questioned for lacking foundational courses in pre-medical studies.

Dong Xi Ying Incident: Peering Through the “Heavenly Palace” Crack – A Glimpse for Ordinary People

  • Unique Family Background:

    • Academic Resource Monopoly: Her father was the secretary of the China Metallurgical and Research Institute, her mother was a deputy director of the North Science University Engineering Technology Research Institute, her grandfather was an academician in the imaging field of Xinhua Medical Institution, and her uncle and aunt were foreign academicians in the materials field at North Science University. This “medicine + research + university” composite family background provided implicit resources such as recommendation letters (requiring recommendations from two biomedical associate professors) and research collaborations (such as North Science University patents).
    • Career Path Leaps: She transitioned from cardiac surgery during residency to urology, with research spanning orthopedics, gastroenterology, radiology, and other fields. This was questioned as “paved road” due to the rapid changes in her career path.

  • Exaggerated Controversy Over Study Duration:

    • Reasonableness of Time Compression: Traditional medical doctorates require 11 years (5+3+3), while the 4+4 program compressed the time to 8 years. Despite Harmony emphasizing “curriculum integration” and “early clinical exposure,” some physicians pointed out that its clinical internship period (12 months) is still less than the traditional eight-year program (18 months), potentially impacting skill accumulation.

  • The Controversy Regarding CCT Reduction: Some CCT bases allowing 4+4 graduates to have a year of CCT reduced are being questioned for undermining industry fairness.

The Medical Education Quagmire Behind the Controversy

The Dong Xiying incident reflects deep contradictions within Chinese medical education:

  1. Conflict between Elitism and Equity:

    • The “application-assessment” model of the 4+4 program is essentially a transplant of the American medical school model, but China lacks standardized exams like MCAT, relying instead on subjective evaluations such as recommendations and research experience, which are significantly influenced by family background.
    • Data shows that among graduates of the 4+4 program in 2023, 30% came from Qingbei Fuzhou (the top universities), and 25% from overseas prestigious schools. The influence of family background on applications is significant.

  2. The Reality of Curriculum Reform:

    • The Cost of Time Compression: 4+4 students produce significantly fewer research outputs (such as the number of publications) than traditional eight-year programs, and are accused of “prioritizing clinical work over research.”
    • Divergence in Industry Recognition: Three-tier hospitals prioritize the reputation of Covance (the name of the top medical school), while基层医院 (jīchéng yīyuàn – primary hospitals) maintain a cautious attitude towards the clinical abilities of 4+4 graduates. - The Confusion Surrounding the International Integration of Medical Education:
  • The US 4+4 model requires passing the MCAT exam and completing a 3-7 year residency, while China’s 4+4 programs have simplified the entry and residency stages, leading to “form resembling but not being” the real thing.
  • Data from the Ministry of Education shows that in 2024, 4+4 programs accounted for less than 5% of national medical doctorate admissions, and their large-scale promotion still faces resistance.

Conclusion: Reconstructing the “Tiangong” Order of Medical Education

The controversy surrounding the CoHo 4+4 project fundamentally represents a clash between elite education and public expectations. When a corner of the “Tiangong” (Heavenly Palace) was glimpsed by mortals, it exposed not just isolated instances of flaws, but deeper contradictions within the entire medical education system. Future reforms must focus on three levels:

  1. Transparent Selection Mechanisms: Introduce standardized exams (such as a Chinese version of MCAT) to reduce the influence of subjective factors like letters of recommendation.
  2. Extend Clinical Training Cycle: Restore the clinical training cycle for 4+4 graduates to 3 years, ensuring that clinical competence is achieved.
  3. Strengthen Process Oversight: Establish an academic integrity review mechanism and conduct rigorous originality verification for interdisciplinary research.

Medical education’s “Tiangong” should not be a privilege reserved for a select few, but rather a true cradle for nurturing medical elites.

item.title: Tariff storm, stock market crash
item.description:
Recently, the global stock markets have experienced significant volatility, primarily due to new measures announced by U.S. President Donald Trump regarding a new round of comprehensive tariffs, which has triggered market concerns about a global trade war and economic recession.

Tariff Policy Sparks Market Panic President Trump announced last week the imposition of high tariffs on all imported goods, with up to 50% tariffs added on imports from China, aimed at correcting what he termed an unfair global trading system. This move led to panic selling across global markets as investors worried that escalating trade tensions would stifle global economic growth.

Global Stock Markets Plunge Sharply In the United States, major indices suffered heavy losses. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell by more than 1,200 points, the Nasdaq Composite declined by 4%, and the S&P 500 dropped 3.8%, entering bear market territory. Asia and Europe were no exception, with the Nikkei 225 in Japan down nearly 8% and European stocks down 6%.

Investors Seek Safe-Haven Assets Faced with market turmoil, investors have been turning to safe-haven assets such as bonds and the Japanese yen. However, the VIX (Volatility Index) surged to above 60, indicating heightened market panic.

Economists Warn of Stagnation Risk Economists warn that trade policies could lead the U.S. economy into “stagflation” – a situation where economic growth stagnates, inflation rises, and unemployment remains high. JPMorgan has raised the probability of a US recession in 2025 to 60%.

Reactions from Governments and Corporations

Governments around the world have indicated they will take retaliatory measures. For example, the European Union’s trade chief stated that tariffs would be imposed on U.S. goods starting April 15th. Businesses have also expressed concerns, with Wall Street firms like Goldman Sachs raising the probability of a U.S. economic recession to 45%.

Conclusion

Currently, the global market is facing unprecedented challenges, and investors must closely monitor trade policy developments and market fluctuations, and implement effective risk management and asset allocation strategies.
